text: - Hello, my name is Ben Traynor.

I work for DataScan
Financial Services company.
I'm the head of information security,
governance, and compliance.

Generative AI is having
two, I think, core impacts.
One is the positive impact.

How can this technology
drive efficiencies?
But that is also the impact

of how do we best protect
against adverse effects

of cyber criminals taking
advantage of this technology.
I think the biggest misconception
about gen AI in the general public
is that it's gonna be the golden hammer
that solves many problems quickly.

We're not there yet. There's
still a lot of innovation.

There's still a lot of thought
that needs to be developed,
so we have to be careful not to rush.

At DataScan how we're
balancing our thought processes
as we head into gen AI,
the security of the model,

the general security
across the infrastructure

is really focusing on what
is the return of investment.
Now, what's critical for our customers
is there might be some use cases
where, yeah, we can drive some revenue,

but what's really important
for us and how we balance this

is that we're not bleeding
edge, we're leading edge.

We're having a thoughtful
process to stepping into this.
AWS is continuing to support DataScan,
not only from a technology perspective

through the vast scale of
services that AWS has provided,

but also from a, you know,
the fact that we can be nimble
with how we adopt those services,
but also from a partnership perspective,
from an innovation perspective,
how we go to market with products,

coming to a customer
as a partner with AWS,
has a degree of robustness.
It's not just us saying it,
we've got a partner coming,

It just builds that vision
and that robustness behind our story.
AWS helps DataScan scale.
It helps us be more agile.

It helps us stay on
the edge of innovation.

It helps us be nimble so we

and also continue to support
